newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia, big powers take India to WTO - Fischer.
newsitem.headline: Australia, big powers take India to WTO - Fischer.

text.p: Australia said on Wednesday it would formally challenge India in the World Trade Organisation (WTO) over balance of payment (BOP) import curbs operated by Delhi.
Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer said Canberra had been joined by major trading powers, including the United States, in formally requesting consultations.

"The restrictions are denying Australian exporters fair access to the Indian market for a whole range of goods, including agricultural commodities, processed foods, precious stones, automotive components, various electrical and mechanical items and textiles," Fischer said in a statement.
"They are major obstacles and can no longer be justified."
Major trading powers and India early this month failed to agree on ending the curbs during talks in Geneva, paving the way for a formal challenge in the world trade body.
Fischer said Australia hoped for an early settlement rather than pursuing the issue in the WTO's dispute settlement body.
India, which has operated restrictions on the imports of thousands of products for more than 40 years on the grounds of balance of payments problems, has offered to phase them out over seven years.
But Australia and the other countries want faster reform, saying India no longer has a balance of payments problem.
